metadata.case_name: Bansilal Abirchand Kasturchand v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Appellant is sole proprietor of firm Bansilal Abirchand Kasturchand, carrying on business as money-lenders, dealers in shares and bullion and commission agents in Bombay, Calcutta and other places. He is resident of Bikaner and manages business through agents.
Agent at Bombay was Chandratan, holding power-of-attorney dated May 13, 1944, conferring large powers of management including authority to operate on bank accounts.

During November 15, 1944 to November 23, 1944, agent withdrew from firm's bank account sums aggregating to Rs. 2,30,636-4-0 and applied them in satisfaction of his personal debts in speculative transactions.
On November 25, 1944, cashier of firm sent telegram to appellant informing him of the true state of affairs.
Appellant went to Bombay on December 3, 1944, and on December 4, 1944, cancelled the power-of-attorney given to the agent.
By notice dated December 6, 1944, appellant called upon agent to pay the amounts withdrawn.
Agent replied on December 8, 1944, admitting misappropriation and pleading for mercy.
On January 16, 1945, appellant filed suit against agent in High Court of Bombay for recovery of Rs. 2,30,636-4-0, decreed on February 20, 1945.
Rs. 28,000 recovered from Chandratan and adjusted towards decree; balance of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 written off as irrecoverable at end of accounting year.
Tribunal found amount represented loss by misappropriation by agent Chandratan but held not trading loss per Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield Ltd.
On application of appellant, Tribunal referred question under s.66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 to Nagpur High Court.
Nagpur High Court held governed by Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield Ltd. and answered against appellant on December 22, 1954 in Misc. Civil Case No. 36 of 1954.
Application under s.66A dismissed; special leave under Art.136 obtained.

legal_issues.text: Whether the said sum of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 being part of the amount embezzled by the assessee's Munim is allowable as a deduction under the Indian Income-tax Act either under Section 10(1) or under the general principles of determining the profit and loss of the assessee or Section 10(2)(xv)?

petitioner_arguments.text: Loss sustained by reason of embezzlement is a bad debt allowable under s.10(2)(xi) of the Act.
It is a business expense falling within s.10(2)(xv) of the Act.
It is a trading loss which must be taken into account in computing the profits under s.10(1) of the Act.
Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield Ltd. is distinguishable; loss incidental to business as in Venkatachalapathy Iyer v. CIT.

respondent_arguments.text: Loss not admissible as deduction per Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield Ltd.; not trading loss.
No evidence that withdrawal by Chandratan was for purpose of making advance; power-of-attorney covered private affairs too.

court_reasoning.text: Deduction not admissible under s.10(2)(xi) as no contractual debt arises from misappropriation; merely journal entries.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Debt must arise from contract; misappropriation is fraud and breach, not contractual obligation.

court_reasoning.text: Not admissible under s.10(2)(xv) as withdrawals unauthorized and fraudulent, not expended for business purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot be expenditure wholly and exclusively for business.

court_reasoning.text: Profits under s.10(1) computed per ordinary commercial principles; deductions not exhaustive in s.10(2); loss from embezzlement by employee incidental to business as employment of agents necessary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Loss springs directly from carrying on business; human nature makes misappropriation possible.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes theft by stranger (not incidental) from employee embezzlement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fine distinction: loss as businessman vs. owner of property.

court_reasoning.text: Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield distinguished: there, managing director's withdrawals de hors trade; here, agent in charge with authority to operate bank in money-lending business where continuous bank operations incidental.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Curtis fact-specific; not broad rule against post-collection embezzlement.

court_reasoning.text: Agrees with Venkatachalapathy Iyer, Lords Dairy Farm, Motipur Sugar Factory: employee defalcation is trading loss.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Withdrawal in purported exercise of authority referable to agency.

court_reasoning.text: Power-of-attorney not extending to private affairs; funds were business funds.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No such issue before IT authorities; their finding assumes business funds.

holdings.text: Loss sustained by appellant as result of misappropriation by Chandratan is incidental to carrying on of business and deductible in computing profits under s.10(1) of the Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Embezzlement by managing director de hors trade; not applicable to agent in money-lending business.
Bad debts deductible under s.10(1) per commercial principles even without specific provision.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles
precedents_cited.relevance: Profits understood in natural commercial sense.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Co. v. Income-tax Commissioner
Jagarnath Therani v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Embezzlement by gumastha incidental to business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramaswami Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Theft by strangers not incidental; supports employee embezzlement allowable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bansidhar Onkarmal v. Commissioner of Income-tax
Venkatachalapathy Iyer v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Accountant's embezzlement by falsifying accounts incidental to business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lords Dairy Farm Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Defalcation by employee is trading loss.

precedents_cited.case_name: Motipur Sugar Factory Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Loss of funds entrusted to employee incidental to trade.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Loss deductible as trading loss under s.10(1); not under s.10(2)(xi) or (xv); reference under s.66(1).

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of High Court set aside; reference answered in affirmative holding the loss deductible under s.10(1).
outcome.relief_granted: Deduction of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 allowed in computing profits.

key_quotes.text: "If employment of agents is incidental to the carrying on of business, it must logically follow that losses which are incidental to such employment are also incidental to the carrying on of the business."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for allowing embezzlement loss as trading loss.

key_quotes.text: "Human nature being what it is, it is impossible to rule out the possibility of an employee taking advantage of his position as such employee and misappropriating the funds of his employer."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why such losses are incidental to business.

key_quotes.text: "What are chargeable in income-tax in respect of a business are the profits and gains of a year and in assessing the amount of the profits and gains of a year account must necessarily be taken of all losses incurred."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites Chitnavis on commercial computation of profits.
